On Decision-Making Agents and Higher-Order Causal Processes

Matt Wilson matthew.wilson@centralesupelec.fr Université Paris-Saclay, CNRS, ENS Paris-Saclay, Inria, CentraleSupélec, Laboratoire Méthodes Formelles
(December 11, 2025)
Abstract

We establish a precise correspondence between decision-making agents in partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) and one-input process functions, the classical limit of higher-order quantum operations. In this identification an agent’s policy and memory update combine into a process function ww that interacts with a POMDP environment via the link product. This suggests a dual interpretation: in the physics view, the process function acts as the environment into which local operations (agent interventions) are inserted, whereas in the AI view it encodes the agent and the inserted functions represent environments. We extend this perspective to multi-agent systems by identifying observation-independent decentralized POMDPs as natural domains for multi-input process functions.

I Introduction

Agency, the capability of an entity to act upon and receive information from its surroundings, is a fundamental notion in both artificial intelligence and the foundations of physics. In AI, agents interact with partially observable environments to maximise cumulative reward, forming the basis of reinforcement learning and multi-agent systems [1, 2]. In the informational foundations of physics, “agents in laboratories” are modelled as local operations inserted into a spacetime environment, formalised by higher-order quantum operations [3, 4, 5, 6]. Both frameworks hinge on the interplay between an agent and its environment, yet they have developed independently and no direct mathematical correspondence between them has been established.

Bridging these viewpoints could bring new ideas to both fields. From a physical perspective, higher-order processes allow causal (even indefinite-causal) structure to be treated as a resource [7, 8, 9]. A mapping to decision-making agents opens the door to consideration of multi-agent tasks in which optimal causal and indefinite causal strategies could be learned. From an AI perspective, interpreting agents as higher-order processes suggests a principled route to quantum generalizations of reward-seeking agency [10, 11, 12].

On the more formal and logic perspective, the compositional and logical tools developed for higher-order quantum maps [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19] and their generalisation to arbitrary monoidal categories [20, 21, 22] might be utilised in the context of such an identification to provide tools for reasoning about composite multi-agent systems. Conversely, already existing compositional and logic tools for modelling aspects of reward-seeking agents and environments in categorical cybernetics [23, 24, 25] and open game theory [26] could be lifted to the quantum domain to bring new techniques and ways of thinking about quantum reinforcement learning [27] and quantum game theory [28].

Contributions. In this work we build a precise correspondence between agents and environments in AI and the foundations of physics. Our main result is a precise correspondence between agent-state deterministic POMDP agents [1, 29] and one-input process functions, the classical limit of higher-order quantum operations [30, 31]. We show that:

  1. 1.

    Every deterministic agent with memory space MM, action set AA and observation set Ω\Omega in the sense of [1, 29] uniquely determines a one-input process function w:(A→Ω)→(M→M)w:(A\!\rightarrow\!\Omega)\rightarrow(M\!\rightarrow\!M) by combining its policy and memory update into a classical comb. Conversely, any one-input process function admits a unique decomposition into a policy and update, yielding a deterministic agent. Two agents are behaviourally equivalent precisely when they induce the same process function.

  2. 2.

    As a result, the same higher-order object admits two dual interpretations: in the physics view, ww represents a spacetime environment into which local operations (agent interventions) are inserted; in the AI view, ww encodes the agent, and the inserted maps represent 11-step evaluations on POMDP environments.

  3. 3.

    Observation-independent decentralised POMDPs provide a natural host for multi-input process functions and thus for multi-agent strategies that may not respect a definite causal order.

These results identify the agents of reinforcement learning with the classical limit of higher-order processes, establishing a direct bridge between agency in AI and agency in physics, with the aim of discovering how causal structure might be used as a resource in AI, whether indefinite causal structures can be efficiently learned, how best to quantize decision-making agents, and how to compose classical and/or quantum multi-agent systems.

II Preliminaries

II.1 Decision–making agents

We will work with deterministic partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) [32]. A deterministic POMDP is defined by the tuple ⟨S,A,Ω,T,O,R⟩\langle S,A,\Omega,T,O,R\rangle where SS is a set of states, AA a set of available actions, Ω\Omega a set of observations and T:S×A→ST:S\times A\rightarrow S, O:S×A→ΩO:S\times A\rightarrow\Omega and R:S×A→ℝR:S\times A\rightarrow\mathbb{R} are deterministic functions specifying the state update, the observation, and the reward associated to performing an action in a given state.

In a fully observable Markov decision process the observation set Ω\Omega coincides with SS, and an optimal agent can choose an action based solely on the current state. In contrast, in a POMDP the observation o∈Ωo\in\Omega at a given time may not uniquely determine the underlying state, and so the agent must retain a memory of the history of its past interactions in order to act optimally. In this article we will work with agent-states which generalise to allow for any agent to retain an abstract memory, representing a suitable compression of the history of past observations [1, 29, 33, 34]. Whilst in these works, agent policies and updates are permitted to be stochastic, we will work entirely within the deterministic picture.

Accordingly, a deterministic agent is specified by two maps:

  1. 1.

    A policy π:M→A\pi:M\rightarrow A that selects an action based on the current memory state.

  2. 2.

    A memory update 𝒰:M×A×Ω→M\mathcal{U}:M\times A\times\Omega\rightarrow M that updates the agent’s memory based on the previous memory, the chosen action and the observed outcome.

The pair 𝒜=(π,𝒰)\mathcal{A}=(\pi,\mathcal{U}) will be called a decision–making agent. Finite‑memory agents generalise both reactive policies π:Ω→A\pi:\Omega\rightarrow A and belief‑state updates, and they do not require the agent to know the environment model in advance.

Whilst the body of this article focusses on the 11-input case. We will later identify a class of POMDPs on which indefinite causal order strategoeis return well-formed logically consistent outcomes, the observation-independent decentralised environments [35].

Definition 1 (nn-party deterministic factored 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP).

Fix n≥2n\geq 2. For each party i∈{1,…,n}i\in\{1,\dots,n\} let SiS_{i} be a local state space, AiA_{i} a local action space, and Ωi\Omega_{i} a local observation space. Define the products

S:=∏i=1nSi,A:=∏i=1nAi,Ω:=∏i=1nΩi.S:=\prod_{i=1}^{n}S_{i},\qquad A:=\prod_{i=1}^{n}A_{i},\qquad\Omega:=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\Omega_{i}.

A deterministic factored nn-party 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP is, simply a POMDP on S,A,ΩS,A,\Omega.

In factored and decentralised POMDPs, we have the opportunity to state constraints on the dependency between actions and observations.

Definition 2 (Observation independence).

The 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP 𝒫\mathcal{P} is observation independent if for each ii the component Oi𝒫​(a,s)O^{\mathcal{P}}_{i}(a,s) is independent of aja_{j} for all j≠ij\neq i. Equivalently, there exist functions

Oi:S×Ai⟶Ωi(i=1,…,n)O_{i}:S\times A_{i}\longrightarrow\Omega_{i}\qquad(i=1,\dots,n)

such that for all a=(a1,…,an)∈Aa=(a_{1},\dots,a_{n})\in A and s∈Ss\in S,

O𝒫​(s,a)=(O1​(s,a1),…,On​(s,an)).O^{\mathcal{P}}(s,a)=\bigl(O_{1}(s,a_{1}),\dots,O_{n}(s,a_{n})\bigr). (1)
Remark.

Equation (1) is the deterministic expression of the no-signalling constraint Ai↛ΩkA_{i}\not\rightarrow\Omega_{k} for i≠ki\neq k within one environment step.

II.2 Process functions

The framework of higher–order quantum operations allows one to treat quantum channels as resources and to compose them in ways that may not respect a fixed causal order [36, 6, 3]. In the classical deterministic limit these higher–order operations reduce to process functions. Such functions are of particular interest because they model deterministic closed timelike curves that remain paradox‑free by ensuring the existence of a unique fixed point for any choice of inserted functions [30]. Here we use the precise formulation given in [31].

Definition 3 (One–input process function).

Let PP, OO, FF and II be sets. A one–input process function of type (I→O)→(P→F)(I\!\rightarrow O)\rightarrow(P\!\rightarrow F) is a function w:P×O→F×Iw:P\times O\rightarrow F\times I satisfying the following unique fixed‑point condition. For every function f:I→Of:I\rightarrow O and every p∈Pp\in P, consider the equation

o=f​(wI​(p,o)),o=f\bigl(w_{I}(p,o)\bigr),

where wI:P×O→Iw_{I}:P\times O\rightarrow I denotes the second component of ww. The map ww is a process function if and only if, for each ff and pp, this equation has a unique solution o∈Oo\in O.

Process functions can be generalised to multiple-inputs, in which case they allow for non-causal concatenations. In this article, we will focus on the 11-input case.

Definition 4 (nn-input process functions).

An nn-input process function is a function

w:P×Ω1×⋯×Ωn⟶F×A1×⋯×Anw:P\times\Omega_{1}\times\cdots\times\Omega_{n}\longrightarrow F\times A_{1}\times\cdots\times A_{n}

satisfying the following unique fixed-point condition: for every choice of deterministic functions

fi:Ai→Ωi(i=1,…,n)f_{i}:A_{i}\rightarrow\Omega_{i}\qquad(i=1,\dots,n)

and every p∈Pp\in P, the system of equations

oi=fi​(wAi​(p,o→))(i=1,…,n)o_{i}=f_{i}\!\bigl(w_{A_{i}}(p,\vec{o})\bigr)\qquad(i=1,\dots,n) (2)

has a unique solution o→=(o1,…,on)∈Ω\vec{o}=(o_{1},\dots,o_{n})\in\Omega. Here wAiw_{A_{i}} denotes the AiA_{i}-component of ww and we write

w​(m,o1,…,on)=(wP​(p,o→),wA1​(p,o→),…,wAn​(p,o→)).w(m,o_{1},\dots,o_{n})=\bigl(w_{P}(p,\vec{o}),\,w_{A_{1}}(p,\vec{o}),\dots,w_{A_{n}}(p,\vec{o})\bigr).

III Correspondence between agents and process functions

To relate agents to process functions we begin by formalising a single round of interaction. Let 𝒜=(π,𝒰)\mathcal{A}=(\pi,\mathcal{U}) be a deterministic agent with memory space MM and let 𝒫=⟨S,A,Ω,T,O,R⟩\mathcal{P}=\langle S,A,\Omega,T,O,R\rangle be a deterministic POMDP. Given an initial memory state m∈Mm\in M and environment state s∈Ss\in S, the one‑step interaction proceeds as follows:

  1. 1.

    The agent chooses an action a=π​(m)a=\pi(m).

  2. 2.

    The environment updates its state to s′=T​(s,a)s^{\prime}=T(s,a), outputs an observation o=O​(s,a)o=O(s,a) and produces a reward r=R​(s,a)r=R(s,a).

  3. 3.

    The agent updates its memory according to m′=𝒰​(m,a,o)m^{\prime}=\mathcal{U}(m,a,o).

We write 𝒜∙𝒫:M×S→M×S×ℝ\mathcal{A}\bullet\mathcal{P}:M\times S\rightarrow M\times S\times\mathbb{R} for the function mapping (m,s)(m,s) to (m′,s′,r)(m^{\prime},s^{\prime},r) defined by this procedure. Two agents should be regarded as behaviourally equivalent if they induce the same memory-state update, environment transition, and reward for every possible environment.

Definition 5.

Let 𝒜=(π𝒜,𝒰𝒜)\mathcal{A}=(\pi_{\mathcal{A}},\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{A}}) and ℬ=(πℬ,𝒰ℬ)\mathcal{B}=(\pi_{\mathcal{B}},\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{B}}) be two deterministic agents with the same memory space. We say that 𝒜\mathcal{A} and ℬ\mathcal{B} are equivalent, written 𝒜≅ℬ\mathcal{A}\cong\mathcal{B}, if for every deterministic POMDP 𝒫\mathcal{P} and every memory–state/environment–state pair (m,s)(m,s) the equality

𝒜∙𝒫​(m,s)=ℬ∙𝒫​(m,s)\mathcal{A}\bullet\mathcal{P}(m,s)\,=\,\mathcal{B}\bullet\mathcal{P}(m,s)

holds.

Concretely, for all POMDPs 𝒫=⟨S,A,Ω,T,O,R⟩\mathcal{P}=\langle S,A,\Omega,T,O,R\rangle and all m∈Mm\in M, s∈Ss\in S one has

T​(s,π𝒜​(m))\displaystyle T\bigl(s,\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m)\bigr) =T​(s,πℬ​(m)),\displaystyle=T\bigl(s,\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m)\bigr),
R​(s,π𝒜​(m))\displaystyle R\bigl(s,\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m)\bigr) =R​(s,πℬ​(m)),\displaystyle=R\bigl(s,\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m)\bigr),
𝒰𝒜​(m,π𝒜​(m),O​(s,π𝒜​(m)))\displaystyle\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{A}}\bigl(m,\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m),O(s,\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m))\bigr) =𝒰ℬ​(m,πℬ​(m),O​(s,πℬ​(m))).\displaystyle=\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{B}}\bigl(m,\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m),O(s,\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m))\bigr).

This definition captures the idea that agents can use different updating mechanisms and still induce the same behaviour.

We now prove that equivalence classes of such agents are in bijection with one‑input process functions. To do so, let us first establish a basic lemma regarding 11-input process functions, that they exhibit a comb-decomposition generalising that of quantum and stochastic higher order processes [36, 7, 15].

Lemma 1 (Decomposition of process functions).

Let w:P×O→F×Iw:P\times O\rightarrow F\times I be a one–input process function. Then there exist functions wF:P×O→Fw_{F}:P\times O\rightarrow F and wI:P→Iw_{I}:P\rightarrow I such that

w​(p,o)=(wF​(p,o),wI​(p)),w(p,o)=\bigl(w_{F}(p,o),\,w_{I}(p)\bigr),

for all p∈Pp\in P and o∈Oo\in O. In particular, wI​(p)w_{I}(p) is independent of oo.

Proof.

Write w​(p,o)=(wF​(p,o),wI​(p,o))w(p,o)=(w_{F}(p,o),w_{I}(p,o)). Suppose for contradiction that there exist o,o′∈Oo,o^{\prime}\in O with wI​(p,o)≠wI​(p,o′)w_{I}(p,o)\neq w_{I}(p,o^{\prime}) for some fixed p∈Pp\in P. Define a function f:I→Of:I\rightarrow O by setting f​(wI​(p,o))=of\bigl(w_{I}(p,o)\bigr)=o and f​(wI​(p,o′))=o′f\bigl(w_{I}(p,o^{\prime})\bigr)=o^{\prime}. The fixed‑point equation o¯=f​(wI​(p,o¯))\bar{o}=f\bigl(w_{I}(p,\bar{o})\bigr) then has two solutions o¯=o\bar{o}=o and o¯=o′\bar{o}=o^{\prime}, contradicting the unique fixed‑point condition. Therefore wI​(p,o)w_{I}(p,o) must be constant as a function of oo, and we may write w​(p,o)=(wF​(p,o),wI​(p))w(p,o)=\bigl(w_{F}(p,o),\,w_{I}(p)\bigr). ∎

This particular form of comb (which is exhaustive in any cartesian monoidal category), is referred to in the categorical literature as a lens [37, 38]. From this lemma we can now connect process functions to desicion-making agents.

Theorem 1.

There is a one‑to‑one correspondence between equivalence classes of deterministic agents and one‑input process functions of type (A→Ω)→(M→M)(A\!\rightarrow\Omega)\rightarrow(M\!\rightarrow M).

Proof.

(Agent ⟹\implies process function). Fix a deterministic agent 𝒜=(π,𝒰)\mathcal{A}=(\pi,\mathcal{U}) with memory space MM, action set AA and observation set Ω\Omega. Define a map

w𝒜:M×Ω⟶M×A,\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{A}}:M\times\Omega\longrightarrow M\times A,
w𝒜​(m,o):=(𝒰​(m,π​(m),o),π​(m)).\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{A}}(m,o):=\bigl(\mathcal{U}(m,\pi(m),o),\,\pi(m)\bigr).

We claim that w𝒜w_{\mathcal{A}} is a one‑input process function. Indeed, for any function f:A→Ωf:A\rightarrow\Omega and any m∈Mm\in M the fixed‑point equation o=f​(w𝒜I​(m,o))o=f\bigl(w_{\mathcal{A}}^{I}(m,o)\bigr) becomes o=f​(π​(m))o=f\bigl(\pi(m)\bigr), which has a unique solution since the right‑hand side is independent of oo.

Now suppose 𝒜≅ℬ\mathcal{A}\cong\mathcal{B}. We show that w𝒜=wℬw_{\mathcal{A}}=w_{\mathcal{B}}. Fix m∈Mm\in M and o∈Ωo\in\Omega. Consider the POMDP 𝒫\mathcal{P} with state space S=Ω×AS=\Omega\times A, transition function T​((o,a′),a)=(o′,a)T((o,a^{\prime}),a)=(o^{\prime},a) (for some fixed state o′o^{\prime}), observation function O​((o,a′),a)=oO((o,a^{\prime}),a)=o and reward function trivial ℛ​((o,a),a)=1\mathcal{R}((o,a),a)=1. For the single step of interaction with starting state (m,(o,a′))(m,(o,a^{\prime})), since 𝒜≅ℬ\mathcal{A}\cong\mathcal{B} we have

𝒜∙𝒫​(m,(o,a′))=ℬ∙𝒫​(m,(o,a′)),\mathcal{A}\bullet\mathcal{P}(m,(o,a^{\prime}))=\mathcal{B}\bullet\mathcal{P}(m,(o,a^{\prime})),

and therefore 𝒰𝒜​(m,π𝒜​(m),o)=𝒰ℬ​(m,πℬ​(m),o)\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{A}}\bigl(m,\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m),o\bigr)=\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{B}}\bigl(m,\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m),o\bigr) and π𝒜​(m)=πℬ​(m)\pi_{\mathcal{A}}(m)=\pi_{\mathcal{B}}(m). It follows that w𝒜​(m,o)=wℬ​(m,o)w_{\mathcal{A}}(m,o)=w_{\mathcal{B}}(m,o) for all m,om,o, and hence equivalent agents induce the same process function.

(Process function ⟹\implies agent). Conversely, let w:M×Ω→M×Aw:M\times\Omega\rightarrow M\times A be a one‑input process function. By the decomposition lemma there are functions wF:M×Ω→Mw_{F}:M\times\Omega\rightarrow M and wI:M→Aw_{I}:M\rightarrow A such that w​(m,o)=(wF​(m,o),wI​(m))w(m,o)=(w_{F}(m,o),w_{I}(m)). We define a deterministic agent 𝒜w\mathcal{A}_{w} with policy πw:=wI\pi_{w}:=w_{I} and memory update 𝒰w​(m,a,o):=wF​(m,o)\mathcal{U}_{w}(m,a,o):=w_{F}(m,o).

We now show that composing these two constructions yields the identity up to equivalence. Starting with a process function ww, constructing the agent 𝒜w=(πw,𝒰w)\mathcal{A}_{w}=(\pi_{w},\mathcal{U}_{w}) and then forming the associated process function w𝒜ww_{\mathcal{A}_{w}} gives

w𝒜w​(m,o)=(𝒰w​(m,πw​(m),o),πw​(m))\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{A}_{w}}(m,o)=\bigl(\mathcal{U}_{w}(m,\pi_{w}(m),o),\,\pi_{w}(m)\bigr)
=(wF​(m,o),wI​(m))=w​(m,o),\displaystyle=\bigl(w_{F}(m,o),\,w_{I}(m)\bigr)=w(m,o),

so w𝒜w=ww_{\mathcal{A}_{w}}=w. Conversely, start with an agent 𝒜=(π,𝒰)\mathcal{A}=(\pi,\mathcal{U}), form w𝒜w_{\mathcal{A}} and then construct the agent 𝒜w𝒜=(πw𝒜,𝒰w𝒜)\mathcal{A}_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}=(\pi_{w_{\mathcal{A}}},\mathcal{U}_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}). One easily checks that πw𝒜=π\pi_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}=\pi and then we have that

𝒰w𝒜​(m,πw𝒜​(m),O​(πw𝒜​(m),s))\displaystyle\mathcal{U}_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}(m,\pi_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}(m),O(\pi_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}(m),s))
=\displaystyle= w𝒜​(m,O​(π​(m),s))\displaystyle w_{\mathcal{A}}(m,O(\pi(m),s))
=\displaystyle= 𝒰w𝒜​(m,π​(m),O​(π​(m),s)),\displaystyle\mathcal{U}_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}(m,\pi(m),O(\pi(m),s)),

and similarly for rewards, so that 𝒜w𝒜≅𝒜\mathcal{A}_{w_{\mathcal{A}}}\cong\mathcal{A}. This shows that the constructions are mutually inverse up-to equivalence and so establishes a bijection between equivalence classes of agents and one‑input process functions. ∎

III.1 Observation-independent 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDPs support indefinite order strategies

We now generalise multi-agent systems in artificial intelligence, allowing for the possibility that they might implement strategies in an indefinite causal order.

Proposition 1 (Multi-agent link product under observation independence).

Let 𝒫\mathcal{P} be a deterministic factored nn-party 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP as in Definition 1. Assume 𝒫\mathcal{P} is observation independent in the sense of Definition 2. Let ww be an nn-input process function as in Definition 4. Then there is a well-defined deterministic map

w⋆𝒫:M×S⟶M×S×ℝw\star\mathcal{P}\;:\;M\times S\longrightarrow M\times S\times\mathbb{R}

computing one step of interaction between ww and the environment 𝒫\mathcal{P}.

Proof.

To define w⋆𝒫w\star\mathcal{P} we must show how to apply it to an arbitrary (m,s)∈M×S(m,s)\in M\times S. By Definition 2, there exist functions Oi:S×Ai→ΩiO_{i}:S\times A_{i}\rightarrow\Omega_{i} such that (1) holds. For the fixed state ss, we then define

fis:Ai→Ωi,fis​(ai):=Oi​(s,ai).f_{i}^{\,s}:A_{i}\rightarrow\Omega_{i},\qquad f_{i}^{\,s}(a_{i}):=O_{i}(s,a_{i}). (3)

Now, consider the fixed point equation

o→i=fis​(wAi​(m,o→))(i=1,…,n).\vec{o}_{i}=f_{i}^{\,s}\!\bigl(w_{A_{i}}(m,\vec{o})\bigr)\qquad(i=1,\dots,n). (4)

Since ww is an nn-input process function, Definition 4 applies to the choice of functions (f1s,…,fns)(f_{1}^{\,s},\dots,f_{n}^{\,s}) and the fixed point equation has a unique solution

o→∗​(m,s)=(o1∗,…,on∗).\vec{o}^{\,*}(m,s)=(o_{1}^{*},\dots,o_{n}^{*}).

We now evaluate ww on this unique fixed point:

(m′,a1∗,…,an∗):=w​(m,o→∗​(m,s)).(m^{\prime},a_{1}^{*},\dots,a_{n}^{*}):=w\bigl(m,\vec{o}^{\,*}(m,s)\bigr). (5)

Let a→∗:=(a1∗,…,an∗)∈A\vec{a}^{\,*}:=(a_{1}^{*},\dots,a_{n}^{*})\in A. Using the decomposition of 𝒫\mathcal{P} from Definition 1, define

(s′,r):=(T𝒫​(s,a→∗),R𝒫​(s,a→∗)).(s^{\prime},r):=\big(T^{\mathcal{P}}(s,\vec{a}^{\,*}),R^{\mathcal{P}}(s,\vec{a}^{\,*})\big). (6)

Finally, we can set

(w⋆𝒫)​(m,s):=(m′,s′,r).(w\star\mathcal{P})(m,s):=(m^{\prime},s^{\prime},r). (7)

This completes the construction. ∎

III.2 Interpretation in Terms of Higher-Order Maps

Quantum supermaps or equivalently process matrices are higher-order transformations that send quantum channels to quantum channels, without assuming a definite causal order [36, 39]. In the deterministic classical limit the same notion of higher-order process is instead captured by process functions [7]. Consequently, we may think of process functions as transformations from functions to functions, and this viewpoint gives a clean way to understand the action of any process function on a POMDP.

Indeed, encoding a deterministic POMDP as a single function is straightforward. Define

𝒫:A×S→Ω×S×ℝ\displaystyle\mathcal{P}:A\times S\rightarrow\Omega\times S\times\mathbb{R}
𝒫​(a,s):=(O​(s,a),T​(s,a),R​(s,a)).\displaystyle\mathcal{P}(a,s):=\bigl(O(s,a),\,T(s,a),\,R(s,a)\bigr).

If w𝒜w^{\mathcal{A}} is the process function associated to an agent 𝒜\mathcal{A} then as seen in the previous section the link product w𝒜⋆𝒫:M×S→M×S×ℝw^{\mathcal{A}}\star\mathcal{P}:M\times S\rightarrow M\times S\times\mathbb{R} computes exactly one step of interaction between the agent and the environment. In the usual graphical notation used to represent higher-order maps in the foundations of physics, this application of a process function to a POMDP via a link product can be expressed by

Furthermore, multi-step interactions correspond to iterated link products. For a finite-horizon task of hh steps one composes the one-step functions w𝒜⋆𝒫w^{\mathcal{A}}\star\mathcal{P} in sequence:

(w𝒜⋆𝒫)h:=(w𝒜⋆𝒫)∘⋯∘(w𝒜⋆𝒫):M×S⟶M×S×ℝh,(w^{\mathcal{A}}\star\mathcal{P})^{h}:=(w^{\mathcal{A}}\star\mathcal{P})\circ\cdots\circ(w^{\mathcal{A}}\star\mathcal{P}):M\times S\longrightarrow M\times S\times\mathbb{R}^{h},

which yields both the final memory and state as well as the sequence of rewards. Again, graphically, this nn-step procedure reads simply as

In this way the process–function formalism points towards a compact graphical framing for the composition of agents, environments, and their cumulative rewards close in spirit to the graphical representations for protocols in categorical cybernetics in terms of coend-optics [23, 25].

For a deterministic observation-independent 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP 𝒫\mathcal{P} and nn-party process function strategy ww with memory space MM, the result of a hh-step interaction is component-wise

(○t=1h(w⋆𝒫))(m0,s0)=(mh,sh,r1,…,rh),(\bigcirc_{t=1}^{h}(w\star\mathcal{P}))(m_{0},s_{0})=(m_{h},s_{h},r_{1},\dots,r_{h}),

where rtr_{t} denotes the reward obtained at time-step tt. As a result of this identification, we can define the discounted reward for an arbitrary process-function strategy.

Definition 6 (Discounted Reward).

Let 𝒫\mathcal{P} be an observation-independent nn-party 𝚍𝚎𝚌\mathtt{dec}-POMDP and ww be an nn-party process function strategy with memory MM. Given a discount factor γ∈[0,1)\gamma\in[0,1) the discounted reward for ww on 𝒫\mathcal{P} with discount γ\gamma is the map

Dw:M×S→ℝD^{w}:M\times S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}

defined by

∑t=1∞γt−1​rt.\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}\gamma^{t-1}\,r_{t}.
Definition 7 (Performance of a Process Function Policy).

Given a distribution μ\mu on SS and memory state m0∈Mm_{0}\in M, define

Ew​(m0,μ):=∑s0∈Sμ​(s0)​Dw​(m0,s0).E^{w}(m_{0},\mu):=\sum_{s_{0}\in S}\mu(s_{0})D^{w}(m_{0},s_{0}).

By the representation for 11-input process functions in terms of a standard agent-state policies, the performance of a 11-input process function policy reduces to the performance of it’s associated agent-state policy as defined in [33]. Nonetheless, the definition can be applied to arbitrary process functions, leaving open the possibility that there might exist observation independent decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes, in which there exist process functions which outperform in the above sense; any policy which operates using a predefined causal order.

IV Conclusion

The correspondence established in this article shows that deterministic agents in artificial intelligence and one‑input process functions in the foundations of physics are mathematically equivalent. Our main result proves a bijection between equivalence classes of finite‑memory POMDP agents and one‑input process functions: combining an agent’s policy and memory update yields a 11-input process function, whilst every such process function decomposes uniquely back into a policy and update. Two agents are behaviorally indistinguishable precisely when they induce the same process function. This correspondence comes with a duality of interpretations: in physics ww is viewed as the spacetime environment into which local operations are inserted, whereas in artificial intelligence ww encodes the agent’s decision‑making procedure and the inserted map corresponds to the environment. Furthermore, we discovered that multi-input process functions yeild legitimate assignments to observation‑independent decision problems.

Regarding future work, with the connection made, precise methods developed for higher‑order causality could now be transported to decision‑making problems. First, is the question of whether there exist practical already known observation independent decentralised-POMDPs [2], in which general process function strategies out perform traditional definite ordered ones, or if it might be possible to build toy examples with indefinite order advantage from well-known causal games such as guess your neighbors input [7]. Furthermore, it is unclear at this stage how efficiently indefinite causal order strategies can be constructed, via a suitable generalization from policy iteration to process-function iteration.

The identification also motivates a particular fully quantum generalization of POMDPs. More precisely, the upgrading of POMDPs from functions to quantum channels of type 𝒫:A×S⟶Ω×S×R\mathcal{P}:A\times S\longrightarrow\Omega\times S\times R with each A,S,Ω,S,RA,S,\Omega,S,R a Hilbert space (with the greatest complication coming from defining a suitable Hilbert space RR for coherently collecting rewards). A quantum decision-making agent in this perspective then corresponds to a (possibly multi-input) quantum super-channel (process matrix). Exactly how this viewpoint compares with the quantum partially observable Markov decision processes of [11], the quantum Markov decision processes of [12], as well as quantum games [28], quantum agents for algorithmic discovery [40], and potential advantages of quantum resources in multi-agent protocols [41], is left for future work.

content.text:
Quick read
- Shows a one-to-one correspondence between finite-memory POMDP agents and one-input process functions from higher-order quantum theory.
- Policies plus memory updates are recast as a single process function; environments become plug-in maps, or vice versa in the physics view.
- Observation-independent dec-POMDPs map cleanly to multi-input process functions, enabling strategies without a fixed causal order.
- Defines discounted reward for process-function strategies and aligns it with agent-state policies when order is definite.
- Open questions: can indefinite causal order beat standard policies; how to iterate/learn such strategies; how to extend to quantum POMDPs and games.

Why it matters
Bridges reinforcement learning and higher-order quantum causality, giving a common language for agents, environments, and rewards, and hinting at quantum advantages in multi-agent decision problems.

If you need full mathematical details (formulas and proofs), open the PDF link at the top; this summary keeps the page lightweight and readable.

es.title: Sobre agentes de toma de decisiones y procesos causales de orden superior
es.content:
Lectura rpida
- Muestra una correspondencia uno a uno entre agentes POMDP con memoria finita y funciones de proceso de una entrada de la teora cuntica de orden superior.
- Las polticas ms las actualizaciones de memoria se reformulan como una sola funcin de proceso; los entornos pasan a ser mapas enchufables, o al revs desde la visin de fsica.
- Los dec-POMDP independientes de la observacin se mapean limpiamente a funciones de proceso de mltiples entradas, habilitando estrategias sin orden causal fijo.
- Define recompensa descontada para estrategias de funciones de proceso y la alinea con polticas de estado del agente cuando el orden es definido.
- Preguntas abiertas: puede el orden causal indefinido superar las polticas estndar; cmo iterar o aprender estas estrategias; cmo extender a POMDPs y juegos cunticos.

Por qu importa
Une el aprendizaje por refuerzo y la causalidad cuntica de orden superior, dando un lenguaje comn para agentes, entornos y recompensas, y sugiriendo ventajas cunticas en problemas de decisin multiagente.

Si necesitas los detalles matemticos completos (frmulas y demostraciones), abre el PDF enlazado arriba; este resumen mantiene la pgina ligera y legible.
